content.description: Sit Start and move left hand up to the only hold that isn't a jug on the route. Then bump your left hand up to a jug (crux). Once on the jug match and make fun-filled moves up to the top.
content.location: Start start on obvious jug just right of the boulder on the ground, 20 feet left of the right arete and a few feet left of tree leaning against the boulder.

content.description: Sit start matched in the finger crack found on the roof of the block. the lefthand is a good jam while the right hand is a sloping pinch. Find a foot and make a huge right hand move to the large flake. Match, then make another huge move to the lip of the roof. Once here, figure out how to match, hit a pair of good nubbins, then get funky with it and believe you are going up to holds that are actually holdable.
content.location: This climb starts under the giant roof in the finger crack. One move gains the large flake. This problem shares the same topout as "Fragments of Time".

content.description: Sit start a foot or two left of The Hills Have Eyes on good holds. Move up to the crimp rail that is fairly obvious. The right hand crimp is better. From here settle your feet and make a long dead point or possibly a dyno if your are on the shorter side to a jug. mantle and top out the easy corner to your left.
content.location: On the right side face of the Headstone Boulder, starts three feet left of the right hand arete.

content.description: Sit start on the right arete of the boulder on a series of positive shelves. Move up to a good left hand full pad crimp now figure out how to get to the jugs above, mantle and top out up path of least resistance to the left.
content.location: On the right side of the Headstone Boulder, start on the right arete on a good shelve and work up and very slightly left. Drop off from jug.

content.description:
Sit start matched on a large shelf found under the massive roof of the boulder. Pull on and make a series of hard moves through the roof crack in order to gain the large flake. Once on the giant flake, make a huge move to the lip and figure out how to pull off a tricky match. Once here, the large holds run out and the slopey nubs provide the climber with a crux top-out sequence. Some how make your way up to the large horizontal crack on the slab then continue up past a giant hands-free rail and eventually to the top of the giant boulder.

 This climb would get more stars, but it is pretty lowball for a few of the roof moves. It is incredible that this climb actually is possible.
content.protection: 6-7 pads. Landing is a bit blocky in spots and a lot of lateral travel happens.
content.location: This problem is found on the downhill side of the giant boulder, underneath the giant roof. The topout for this problem faces the trail, and is literally right next to a sign with a map of the area.

content.description: One of the largest boulders in the Black Jack Boulders, also the furthest west. The rock has a lot of potential, but needs a lot of cleaning.On the right side of the boulder (facing uphill toward the crags) has the most potential.The front really tall face (about 35 feet) could have some TR routes, not sure about gear routes from the ground it doesn't look like it but there may be some small protection that is not visible from the ground.
